climbs.name: Wayne's World
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Mary Ann Loehr, and Wayne, 3/1997

content.description: Easy start to reach the interior of a flake with an overhanging bottom, which leads up onto the outside arete fin that forms the right side of the Nestle's Crunch dihedral. Pretty wild. Pretty cool. Finish via the fingers-to-hands crack of Sugar Daddy and Nestle's Crunch.
content.protection: Pro to 2.5", anchor gear options way back, even if incorporating the topside anchor bolts (no rap links) of Bare Leigh Legal to climber's left.  Bad direction if using only BLL anchor bolts.

climbs.name: The Three Musketeers
climbs.fa: Todd Swain, Jim Browning, and John Thackray, April 1990

content.description: This face climb is on the wall just across from the northeast corner of Little Rock Candy Mountain.

climbs.name: Sugar Daddy
climbs.fa: Chick Holtkamp and John Lakey, February 1978

content.description: This climb has awkward finger jamming crux on good rock.  It starts up a left-facing corner on the west face, and continues up a crack to the top.

climbs.name: Squirrel Roast
climbs.fa: Alan Bartlett and Kilian Bauz, April 1988

content.description: A fun, runout and exposed knobby face climb.
content.location: To the right of Kendall Mint Cake on the north face.

climbs.name: Nestle's Crunch
climbs.fa: Chick Holtkamp, Forrest and Dan, December 1978

content.description:
Located on the southwest face of Little Rock Candy Mountain, this is the route to the right of Sugar Daddy. An easy start leads to a very thin corner. Good feet at the base of the corner fade, requiring multiple moves of stemming. Follow the corner up to the roof. Undercling and reach for the 5' roof move. The route then joins Sugar Daddy for easy climbing to the top.

Unless you have very thin fingers, this route requires multiple stemming moves. A good precursor to the more challenging stemming routes.
content.protection: Small nuts, multiple purple/blue tcu's.  Smattering of hand size for upper crack/belay.

climbs.name: My Balls feel like a Pair of Maracas

content.description: Start off a big boulder to climb this bigger boulder with a high first clip. Fun but slightly grainy liebacking gets you to the cool little summit.
content.protection: Two bolts and two fixed pins gets you to a two bolt anchor rap.
content.location: Right above Three Musketeers. On a big block.

climbs.name: McStumpy  Sandwich
climbs.fa: Alan Bartlett, Don Reid, Todd Gordon & Cyndie Bransford, April 1988

content.description: Started out on a rail and moved up and slightly right towards the bolt 20 or so feet up.  Above the bolt the rock is solid and the climbing gets steep  climbing past a horizontal and through some thin seems. One of my favorite leads as far as keeping my head together goes. Good Times!!!!Rap off M&Ms plain.
content.protection: One bolt + a light rack for the climbing. I could not seem to find anything worthy of placing past the bolt (You may find something). Large pro for anchor.

climbs.name: M & Ms Plain
climbs.fa: Chick Holtkamp and John Lakey, February 1978

content.description: A short and awkward climb up the most obvious of the two cracks on this face.  The crux comes about ten feet off the ground and involves an balancy move from the flaring crack onto the face.Difficult to protect and not recommended.
content.protection: Protects with small cams and nuts.  Bolted anchor.

climbs.name: M & M's Peanut
climbs.fa: Chick Holtkamp and John Lakey, February 1978

content.description: This the crack that is 3' left of M&Ms Plain and is a thin crack that goes to fists higher up. Coming in from the right is easier than the direct start on this route that is more a face climb than a crack climb.
content.protection: Small wires down low, small cams higher up

climbs.name: Little Rock Candy Crack
climbs.fa: Chick Holtkamp and John Lakey, February 1978

content.description: This route is the left slanting crack to the far right of M&M's Plain.  Start below several sloping flared horizontal cracks.  Head up the horizontals then gain the main crack and follow it up to the top.
content.protection: Pro to 2.5 inches.  Belay from shallow flared crack at top.

content.description: An excellent route up the sunny southwestern corner of the formation.  It starts in a shallow corner with a thin crack (5.9ish).  After a couple moves to the top of the corner, move slightly left to the exposed arête.  Climb the large patina plates on the arête to the top.  Pro includes TCUs and maybe a slung plate or two.  It looks questionable from below, but ends up having solid placements right where you need them (PG).  The best route on the crag.

climbs.name: Kendall Mint Cake
climbs.fa: Bob Yoho and Chick Holtkamp, February 1978

content.description: This is a secure, knobby hand crack on the left side of the north face.  Rappel from the top.

climbs.name: Jolly Rancher Firestix
climbs.fa: Chick Holtkamp and John Lakey, December 1978; Direct Start: (TR) Chris Miller and Tim Fearn, February 1988

content.description:
An easy start up blocky ledges gets one to the base of a smooth water worn groove. Climb this with little to no protection to reach a horizontal crack then move left and finish in a thin crack, the left of two.

Good climbing on this but the poor protection makes this perhaps best as a toprope.

A direct start has been toproped by climbing the faint seam just to the left of the groove, which takes one directly to the upper thin crack.
content.protection: A minimal rack to 2 inches or a TR
content.location:
Located between

Chicken Bones

and

Lips Like Sugar

.

content.description: This is a short, clean, narrow (4 inch) offwidth, near the left end of the east face.

climbs.name: Creme Egg
climbs.fa: John Thackray and Todd Swain, April 1990

content.description:
Start from a boulder at the base and climb a line that moves up and left to parallel

Little Rock Candy Crack

.
content.location:
Located on the face just left of

Little Rock Candy Crack

.

content.description:
Climb

The Three Musketeers

to it's second bolt and then break left up the featured face to the top.
content.location:
Just left of

The Three Musketeers

.

climbs.name: Chicken Bones
climbs.fa: Chick Holtkamp and John Lakey, February 1978

content.description: This is a short steep face with large, widely spaced holds.  I found it to be much harder than its listed rating of 5.4.  On the west face, follow a crack (face climbing) to a ledge half way up, then traverse right into a left-facing corner, and follow that to the top.

climbs.name: Butterfingers
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Patty Kline, November 2001

content.description: Start in a short vertical crack and then climb straight up the face staying between the other two routes on either side.
content.location:
Located on the face between

Little Rock Candy Crack

and

McStumpy  Sandwich

.

content.description: Step across gap onto face, head up past 6 bolts through one roof (or go around to the left) head up a steep holdless arete, and through another roof. Two bolt anchor with chains.
content.location:
Southwest corner of Little Rock Candy Mountain. Five feet to the left of

Sugar Daddy

; it seems a bit contrived until the hard climbing starts.
